search_results.content: Best Business Credit Cards Hims is officially phasing out its copycat weight-loss drugs, and the company's stock tumbled — again Hims and Hers is phasing out its compounded weight loss drugs (not pictured). Hims and Hers plans to stop selling compounded weight loss drugs after an FDA update. Hims and Hers' stock fell over 19% in after-hours trading on Monday after its CEO said the company would no longer sell compounded versions of mega-hit weight loss drugs. Earlier this month, Hims ran a Super Bowl ad touting the affordability of its weight loss drugs compared to those sold by big pharmaceutical companies. In its earnings report, Hims credited these weight-loss drugs for growth in online revenue in 2024.

fact_check.explanation: The statement attributed to the Hims CEO is likely fabricated or taken out of context, as it does not align with the formal communication style typically found in corporate press releases. Given the serious nature of financial announcements and company communications, such informal remarks, especially with a nickname like 'the Puppetmaster of Phalluses', raise suspicions of misinformation. Moreover, no credible source supports this statement, leading to a high likelihood of it being misleading.

search_results.title: Cackling Hims CEO Threatens To Pull Switch Activating All World's ...
search_results.content: SAN FRANCISCO—Warning that every flaccid member across the globe now represented a ticking time bomb in his hands, cackling Hims CEO Joseph Ludlum released a statement Friday in which he threatened to pull a switch that would activate all the world’s erections at once. “Citizens of Earth, we at Hims have long served as overseers of your sexual health, and today we come with a simple request: $10 trillion by midnight, or we will trigger every last one of your erections,” Joseph Ludlum said in the video, letting out a high-pitched laugh as he marveled at how easy wresting control of the world’s phalluses had been.

fact_check.explanation: The given text appears to be a fictional continuation of an already absurd story involving Hims CEO Joseph Ludlum. The original content is satire from The Onion, which is known for publishing exaggerated and humorous takes on real-world themes. Thus, the presentation of this narrative as factual information constitutes full misinformation, as it is entirely satirical and not intended to be taken seriously.
